March 18, 2007: Fiction
SHOPAHOLIC & BABY, by Sophie Kinsella. (Dial, $24.) Becky is pregnant, and
the obstetrician turns out to be her husband’s ex-girlfriend.
STEP ON A CRACK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) A detective raising 10 children alone must rescue 34 high-level hostages.
INNOCENT IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $25.95) Lt. Eve Dallas
investigates the murder of an apparently inoffensive private-school history teacher;
by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
SISTERS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) After a family tragedy, four sisters
with very different lives decide to share a Manhattan brownstone.
THE WATCHMAN, by Robert Crais. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A former Los
Angeles police officer becomes the bodyguard of a troubled heiress marked for
death.
THE DOUBLE BIND, by Chris Bohjalian. (Shaye Areheart, $25.) A young woman
who works at a homeless shelter struggles to understand the mysterious
photographs taken by a recently deceased resident.
THE ALEXANDRIA LINK, by Steve Berry. (Ballantine, $25.95.) A former Justice
Department operative turned bookseller hides a link to the secrets of the vanished
library of Alexandria from wealthy international thugs.
PLUM LOVIN’, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin’s, $16.95.) A mysterious man in
Stephanie Plum’s life helps her track down a matchmaker who skipped bail.
FOR ONE MORE DAY, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $21.95.) A troubled man gets
a last chance to reconnect and restore his relationship with his dead mother.
HEART-SHAPED BOX, by Joe Hill. (Morrow, $24.95.) An aging rock star who
buys what’s advertised as a ghost online to add to his collection of macabre
objects is stunned when it turns out to be the real thing.
HIGH PROFILE, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $24.95.) Jesse Stone, the police
chief of Paradise, Mass., investigates the deaths of a controversial talk-show host
and a young woman.
THE TASTE OF INNOCENCE, by Stephanie Laurens. (Morrow, $24.95.) In 19th-
century England, an aristocrat makes a sensible match, but his wife wants him to
love her; Laurens’s 14th Cynster novel.
FAMILY TREE, by Barbara Delinsky. (Doubleday, $25.95.) A white woman
searches for the father she never knew after she unexpectedly gives birth to a
black child.
March 18, 2007
Non-Fiction
IN AN INSTANT, by Lee and Bob Woodruff. (Random House, $25.95.) The
aftermath of the ABC co-anchor’s traumatic brain injury in Iraq in 2006.
THE AUDACITY OF HOPE, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.) The Illinois junior
senator proposes that Americans move beyond their political divisions.
SOMEBODY’S GOTTA SAY IT, by Neal Boortz (HC/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A
radio talk-show host discusses government, poverty, prayer in the schools, race
relations, gun control and other topics.
A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing
spree and his return to humanity.
INFIDEL, by Ayaan Hirsi Ali. (Free Press, $26.) A memoir by the Somali-born
advocate for Muslim immigrant women, once a member of the Dutch Parliament,
who has been threatened with death.
THE JESUS FAMILY TOMB, by Simcha Jacobovici and Charles Pellegrino.
(HarperSanFrancisco, $27.95.) The discovery of ossuaries that, the authors say,
may contain the remains of Jesus, Mary Magdalene and their son.
THE INNOCENT MAN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Grisham’s first
nonfiction book concerns a man sentenced to death for a crime he did not commit.
I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at
aging from a novelist and screenwriter (‘‘When Harry Met Sally’’).
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $29.95 and $21.95.) A newspaper
columnist and his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $27.95.)
A maverick scholar and a journalist apply economic theory to nearly everything.
PALESTINE PEACE NOT APARTHEID, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster,
$27.) The former president calls for revitalizing the peace process.
BORN ON A BLUE DAY, by Daniel Tammet. (Free Press, $24.) A memoir by an
autistic savant who can perform extraordinary mathematical calculations.
THE GOD DELUSION, by Richard Dawkins. (Houghton Mifflin, $27.) An Oxford
scientist asserts that belief in God is irrational.
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) A
columnist for The Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
